subject: Law
title: International IP Protection
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: International IP Protection.

hook.text: A US patent means nothing in China. IP rights are territorialâ€”they stop at the border.

buildup.text: IP rights are granted by individual countries. There is no single worldwide patent or copyright.

discovery.text: Treaties like TRIPS and the Paris Convention set minimum standards that member countries must follow.

twist.text: Enforcement varies wildly. Some countries have strong IP courts; others barely enforce IP laws at all.

climax.text: Companies must register and enforce IP in every country where they do businessâ€”an expensive process.

punchline.text: IP is local. Business is global. That gap creates conflict.

quiz.question: What does TRIPS do for international IP?
options: Sets minimum IP standards for member countries
